title: Vicinity bolsters balance sheet with major debt deal in Europe
text:
Shopping mall giant Vicinity Centres, the joint owner of the country's biggest mall, took advantage of the globally low cost of debt, pricing €500 million ($809 million) worth of medium-term notes in the European market.

Vicinity's move is the latest in a run of major debt raisings by retail landlords. In March, Scentre, which owns Westfield malls in Australia, priced €500 million in the European market.

Earlier this month, Unibail-Rodamco-Westfield, the global malls giant that took over Westfield last year, priced a €750 million bond offering, with a long 12-year maturity and a 0.875 per cent fixed coupon.

The Vicinity 10-year notes were issued with a 1.125 per cent coupon. More than 50 accounts participated in the final book, wooed by the strength of Vicinity’s single-A credit rating.

Grant Kelley

“We are very pleased with the strong response that we received for this inaugural euro-denominated medium-term note raising, which has resulted in highly competitive pricing for our notes," managing director Grant Kelley said.
description: Vicinity's move is the latest in a run of major debt raisings by retail landlords.
